inference:
Solution:
- There are $3\times3\times3=27$ one-inch cubes.
- The cubes on each of the six faces have red paint on at least one face. 
- Of these, the cubes on the edges have red paint on two faces.
- There are 12 edges on a cube, and each edge has 1 cube with red paint on two faces.
- The cubes on the corners have red paint on three faces.
- There are 8 corners on a cube.
- Therefore, the total number of cubes with red paint on at least two faces is $12+8=20$. 

Final Answer: $\boxed{20}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Only the $8$ corners of the cube have three faces painted red. Each edge has one cube that has $2$ faces painted red. There are $12$ edges, so $12$ cubes have $2$ faces painted red. Each of the six faces has only the center cube painted on exactly $1$ face, and the single cube in the center of the three-inch cube is the only one with no faces painted. We can thus produce the following table: $$
\begin{array}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Number of red faces} & \textbf{Number of one-inch cubes} \\
\hline
\ast3 & 8 \\
\hline
\ast2 & 12 \\
\hline
1 & 6 \\
\hline
0 & 1 \\
\hline
\multicolumn{2}{|r|}{
\text{Total = 27}}\\
\hline
\end{array}
$$$\ast$ Number of cubes with $2$ or $3$ red faces is $8 + 12 = \boxed{20}.$
